title: Amazon Catholic bishops call for church to allow married men to be ordained
text:
Catholic bishops in the Amazon on Saturday called for the church to allow married men to be ordained as priests to help reverse a clergy shortage in the area.

The majority of the 180 bishops from nine Amazonian countries also voted for the Catholic Church to revive a debate regarding ordaining women as deacons.

The proposals were approved Saturday at the conclusion of a three-week synod on the Amazon. Pope Francis Pope FrancisLouisiana GOP bring in big names to block Democratic governor Pompeo, Pope Francis urge protections of religious freedom The Hill's Morning Report — Trump takes aim at whistleblower MORE called for the gathering back in 2017 to try to hammer out plans to save the rainforest and better minister to indigenous tribes in the area.

The Catholic Church already allows married men to be ordained in Eastern Rite churches and permits married Anglican men who convert to be ordained. However, should Pope Francis approve the latest proposal, it would mark the first time Latin Rite churches allow married men to become priests. It would also mark a significant change in tradition for the Catholic priesthood overall.

The proposal calls for the church to craft criteria “to ordain priests suitable and esteemed men of the community, who have had a fruitful permanent diaconate and receive an adequate formation for the priesthood, having a legitimately constituted and stable family, to sustain the life of the Christian community through the preaching of the Word and the celebration of the sacraments in the most remote areas of the Amazon region.”

Francis has long lauded celibacy, saying it helps grant discipline, but has voiced willingness to mull changing the practice since it is tradition rather than doctrine.

The celibate priesthood has been a part of the Latin Rite Catholic Church since the 11th century.
